title: John Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on John chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: John Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of John Chapter 2.

questions.question: Where did the marriage take place in John Chapter 2?
options: Cana of Galilee
Nazareth
Jerusalem
Bethlehem
questions.correctAnswer: Cana of Galilee
questions.explanation: John 2:1 states that the marriage was in Cana of Galilee.

questions.question: Who was present at the marriage in Cana according to John 2?
options: Jesus and his mother
Jesus and the Pharisees
Jesus and Pilate
Jesus and the Romans
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus and his mother
questions.explanation: John 2:1 mentions that the mother of Jesus was there, and John 2:2 says Jesus was called to the marriage.

questions.question: What did Jesus' mother say to him about the wine at the marriage?
options: They have no wine
They have plenty of wine
The wine is spoiled
The wine is too strong
questions.correctAnswer: They have no wine
questions.explanation: John 2:3 records Jesus' mother saying, 'They have no wine.'

questions.question: How did Jesus respond to his mother when she said they had no wine?
options: Woman, what have I to do with thee? mine hour is not yet come
Do as I say
I will provide more wine
Wait until later
questions.correctAnswer: Woman, what have I to do with thee? mine hour is not yet come
questions.explanation: John 2:4 records Jesus' response to his mother with these exact words.

questions.question: What instruction did Jesus' mother give to the servants?
options: Whatsoever he saith unto you, do it
Fill the jars with wine
Ignore his words
Prepare more food
questions.correctAnswer: Whatsoever he saith unto you, do it
questions.explanation: John 2:5 records the mother of Jesus instructing the servants to do whatever Jesus tells them.

questions.question: How many waterpots were there, and what were they used for?
options: Six waterpots of stone, for Jewish purification
Twelve waterpots of clay, for drinking
Four waterpots of metal, for washing
Ten waterpots of wood, for cooking
questions.correctAnswer: Six waterpots of stone, for Jewish purification
questions.explanation: John 2:6 describes six stone waterpots used according to the manner of Jewish purification.

questions.question: What miracle did Jesus perform with the waterpots at the marriage?
options: He turned water into wine
He purified the waterpots
He multiplied the water
He made the water cold
questions.correctAnswer: He turned water into wine
questions.explanation: John 2:9-10 shows that the water was miraculously turned into wine, which was of better quality than before.

questions.question: Who tasted the wine and commented on its quality?
options: The ruler of the feast
Jesus' mother
The bridegroom himself
The disciples
questions.correctAnswer: The ruler of the feast
questions.explanation: John 2:9 states the ruler of the feast tasted the water made wine and praised it.

questions.question: What did the ruler of the feast say about the wine Jesus provided?
options: Thou hast kept the good wine until now
This wine is sour
The wine is ordinary
We have better wine earlier
questions.correctAnswer: Thou hast kept the good wine until now
questions.explanation: John 2:10 records the ruler of the feast saying that the good wine was kept until last.

questions.question: What was the significance of this miracle in Cana?
options: It was the beginning of Jesus' miracles and manifested his glory
It was a common event with no significance
It was a secret kept from the disciples
It was a test of people's faith
questions.correctAnswer: It was the beginning of Jesus' miracles and manifested his glory
questions.explanation: John 2:11 states this was the beginning of miracles Jesus did, manifesting his glory and causing his disciples to believe.

questions.question: True or False: After the marriage in Cana, Jesus and his family stayed in Capernaum for many days.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 2:12 says Jesus and his family continued there not many days, indicating a short stay.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus found those selling animals and money changers in the temple at Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 2:14 states Jesus found oxen, sheep, doves sellers and money changers in the temple.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus made a scourge of small cords and drove out the sellers and money changers from the temple.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 2:15 tells how Jesus made a scourge and drove them all out of the temple.

questions.question: Complete the verse from John 2:16: 'Make not my Father's house an house of ______.'
options: merchandise
prayer
peace
law
questions.correctAnswer: merchandise
questions.explanation: John 2:16 records Jesus saying, 'make not my Father's house an house of merchandise.'

questions.question: According to John 2, what did Jesus mean by 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up'?
options: He referred to the temple of his body
He meant the physical temple in Jerusalem
He was speaking about a new building
He was talking about the temple priests
questions.correctAnswer: He referred to the temple of his body
questions.explanation: John 2:21 clarifies that Jesus spoke about the temple of his body.

medium.title: John Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from John Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does the miracle of turning water into wine at the wedding in Cana teach us about obedience and trust in Jesus?
options: Obeying Jesus leads to witnessing His glory and blessing
We should only trust Jesus after seeing miracles
Jesus requires us to solve problems before He acts
Wine was unimportant at the wedding
questions.correctAnswer: Obeying Jesus leads to witnessing His glory and blessing
questions.explanation: In John 2:5-11, Jesus' mother tells the servants to do whatever Jesus says, and their obedience results in a miraculous blessing, showing that trusting and obeying Jesus leads to His glory being revealed.

questions.question: A fellow believer is worried about whether God’s timing is right for their prayers. Based on Jesus’ words in John 2, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God’s timing is perfect even if it differs from ours
We should always demand immediate answers
God does not care about our requests
Timing is unimportant in faith
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing is perfect even if it differs from ours
questions.explanation: Jesus says, 'Mine hour is not yet come' (John 2:4), illustrating that God’s timing governs His actions, and believers must trust His perfect plan and patience (John 2:1-4, 23-25).

questions.question: How does Jesus’ cleansing of the temple in John 2 teach about integrity and reverence in worship?
options: God’s house should be kept pure and free from dishonest practices
It is acceptable to mix business with worship
Worship is only about personal feelings
Money handling is unrelated to faith
questions.correctAnswer: God’s house should be kept pure and free from dishonest practices
questions.explanation: Jesus drives out the merchants and money changers (John 2:14-16) because the temple was being misused, teaching believers that integrity and reverence are essential in worship and church life (John 2:14-17).

questions.question: What lesson about faith and belief can be drawn from the disciples’ reaction to Jesus’ first miracle in Cana?
options: Witnessing God’s works strengthens faith
Faith does not require evidence
Miracles happen only to special people
Belief is unnecessary for followers
questions.correctAnswer: Witnessing God’s works strengthens faith
questions.explanation: John 2:11 states that Jesus' first miracle manifested His glory and caused the disciples to believe in Him, showing that experiencing God's works can strengthen our faith (John 2:11, 23-24).

questions.question: In John 2, Jesus speaks about destroying the temple and raising it in three days. How does this passage teach about spiritual understanding beyond literal interpretations?
options: True spiritual meaning often transcends physical appearances
All scripture must be taken only literally
Jesus was speaking about a new building
The temple was not important
questions.correctAnswer: True spiritual meaning often transcends physical appearances
questions.explanation: Jesus referred to His body as the temple (John 2:19-21), teaching that spiritual truths may be deeper than the literal, encouraging believers to seek spiritual insight (John 2:19-22).

questions.question: How does Jesus’ knowledge of human hearts in John 2:24-25 encourage humility and sincerity in our walk with God?
options: God knows our true motives, so we should be sincere and humble
We can hide anything from God
Only outward appearances matter to God
God needs human testimony to understand us
questions.correctAnswer: God knows our true motives, so we should be sincere and humble
questions.explanation: Jesus did not commit Himself to everyone because He knew what was in man (John 2:24-25), reminding believers to maintain genuine humility and transparency before God (John 2:24-25).

questions.question: A believer is facing the challenge of temptation and doubts. Based on John 2, what practical encouragement can be given regarding perseverance through trials?
options: Faith grows through trusting God’s timing and purposes
Temptation means God has abandoned us
We should abandon faith when trials come
Miracles guarantee a life without trials
questions.correctAnswer: Faith grows through trusting God’s timing and purposes
questions.explanation: Jesus’ statement about His hour not yet coming (John 2:4) and the disciples believing after seeing signs (John 2:11, 23-24) show that perseverance based on trust in God’s plans leads to spiritual growth.

questions.question: How does the instruction of Jesus’ mother to 'do whatever he tells you' (John 2:5) model spiritual obedience for Christian living?
options: Obedience to Jesus’ commands brings blessings and fulfillment
We should judge Jesus’ commands before obeying
Obedience is optional in faith
Doing what Jesus says is only for servants
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to Jesus’ commands brings blessings and fulfillment
questions.explanation: Mary’s instruction to the servants (John 2:5) leads to the miracle of water becoming wine, demonstrating that obedience to Christ results in His provision and glory being revealed (John 2:5-11).

questions.question: True or False: The ruler of the feast recognized immediately that the wine Jesus provided was superior to the earlier wine served.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 2:9-10 shows the ruler of the feast tasted the water made wine and recognized it was better than the earlier wine, highlighting God's provision and abundance.

questions.question: True or False: Jesus committed Himself fully to everyone who believed in Him at the Passover in Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John 2:23-24 states that many believed because of the miracles, but Jesus did not commit Himself to them fully because He knew their hearts, emphasizing discernment in faith (John 2:23-25).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The waterpots at the wedding in Cana were used "after the manner of the _______ of the Jews."
options: purifying
feasting
blessing
serving
questions.correctAnswer: purifying
questions.explanation: John 2:6 describes that the six stone waterpots were according to the Jewish custom of purification, illustrating respect for religious traditions and spiritual cleanliness.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ action of driving out the merchants with a scourge of cords in the temple teach about righteous anger and protecting God's holiness?
options: Righteous anger is appropriate to defend God's holiness against misuse
Anger is never acceptable in any situation
Jesus tolerated all actions in the temple
God’s house is a place for commerce
questions.correctAnswer: Righteous anger is appropriate to defend God's holiness against misuse
questions.explanation: John 2:14-16 shows Jesus actively cleansing the temple, teaching believers that zeal for God's holiness can rightly express itself in defending sacred spaces and values.

questions.question: What does the reaction of the disciples in remembering scripture after Jesus spoke about the temple teach about spiritual growth and reflection?
options: Reflecting on Jesus’ words with scripture deepens faith
Scripture is unrelated to Jesus’ teachings
Believers should ignore past teachings
Faith does not require understanding
questions.correctAnswer: Reflecting on Jesus’ words with scripture deepens faith
questions.explanation: John 2:17 and 22 show the disciples recalled scripture to understand Jesus’ actions and words, highlighting the importance of reflection and connecting scripture with life events for spiritual growth.

questions.question: Based on John 2, what should be the attitude of a Christian toward sharing their faith when seeing others believe because of miracles?
options: Encourage belief but recognize true faith comes from understanding and heart transformation
Only miracles can bring genuine faith
Faith should be forced upon others
Belief is unimportant
questions.correctAnswer: Encourage belief but recognize true faith comes from understanding and heart transformation
questions.explanation: John 2:23-24 shows many believed because of miracles, but Jesus did not fully commit Himself because He knew their hearts, teaching that faith must go beyond signs to true heart transformation.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ interaction with His mother at the wedding in Cana model family relationships in Christian life?
options: Respect and cooperation within the family lead to God’s blessing
Family disagreements should be ignored
Parents have no role in spiritual matters
Family is unrelated to faith
questions.correctAnswer: Respect and cooperation within the family lead to God’s blessing
questions.explanation: John 2:1-5 shows a respectful interaction where Mary brings a concern to Jesus and He acts, teaching believers the value of honoring family roles and working together in faith.

hard.title: John Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from John Chapter 2.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus' first miracle at Cana in John 2, considering Old Testament typology?
options: It foreshadows the Messianic banquet and God's provision in the new covenant
It symbolizes the Exodus from Egypt
It depicts the anointing of King David
It represents the parting of the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the Messianic banquet and God's provision in the new covenant
questions.explanation: John 2:1-11 describes Jesus turning water into wine at a wedding, symbolizing the Messianic banquet and abundant blessing anticipated in the new covenant (cf. Isaiah 25:6).

questions.question: In John 2:4, Jesus refers to 'mine hour is not yet come.' What does this phrase imply in Johannine theology?
options: The appointed time of Jesus' passion and glorification has not yet arrived
Jesus is unwilling to perform miracles
Jesus doubts his mission
Jesus intends to delay his ministry
questions.correctAnswer: The appointed time of Jesus' passion and glorification has not yet arrived
questions.explanation: The phrase 'mine hour' (John 2:4) in John often signifies the predetermined time of Jesus' suffering, death, and glorification (cf. John 7:30; 12:23).

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of the six waterpots mentioned in John 2:6?
options: They were used for Jewish ceremonial purification rituals
They were for ordinary drinking water
They were used to store grain
They were decorative items
questions.correctAnswer: They were used for Jewish ceremonial purification rituals
questions.explanation: John 2:6 notes the waterpots were 'after the manner of the purifying of the Jews,' indicating their use in ritual washing, a significant aspect of Jewish purity laws (cf. Leviticus 15).

questions.question: How does the reaction of the ruler of the feast (John 2:9-10) symbolize the reversal of expectations in Jesus' ministry?
options: The best wine is saved until last, contrary to common practice
The wine was sour from the start
The feast was ending prematurely
The guests were dissatisfied with the wine
questions.correctAnswer: The best wine is saved until last, contrary to common practice
questions.explanation: John 2:10 highlights how the best wine was saved until the end, reversing traditional expectations and symbolizing the superior blessings of the messianic age through Jesus.

questions.question: What does the term 'temple' signify in Jesus’ statement, 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up' (John 2:19) according to John 2:21?
options: His own body as the true temple
The Jerusalem temple building
The synagogue in Capernaum
The tabernacle in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: His own body as the true temple
questions.explanation: John 2:21 clarifies that Jesus spoke metaphorically about his body as the temple, foreshadowing his death and resurrection.

questions.question: How does Jesus’ cleansing of the temple in John 2:14-16 serve as a critique of Second Temple Judaism practices?
options: It condemns commercialization and corruption within the temple precincts
It supports the money changers' activities
It approves of selling animals for sacrifice
It encourages the temple authorities
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns commercialization and corruption within the temple precincts
questions.explanation: John 2:14-16 depicts Jesus driving out merchants, emphasizing his zeal for the sanctity of the temple, opposing its misuse for profit.

questions.question: What Old Testament scripture do the disciples recall in John 2:17 when Jesus shows zeal for God's house?
options: Psalm 69:9
Isaiah 53:5
Genesis 1:1
Exodus 20:3
questions.correctAnswer: Psalm 69:9
questions.explanation: John 2:17 refers to Psalm 69:9, 'The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up,' connecting Jesus' temple zeal with prophetic fulfillment.

questions.question: How does the concept of Jesus 'knowing all men' in John 2:24-25 relate to his ability to discern human hearts as depicted in the Old Testament?
options: It parallels divine omniscience, emphasizing Jesus' divine nature
It suggests Jesus was merely a good judge
It implies Jesus needed human testimony
It denies Jesus’ knowledge of people
questions.correctAnswer: It parallels divine omniscience, emphasizing Jesus' divine nature
questions.explanation: John 2:24-25 highlights Jesus' divine insight into human nature, similar to God's omniscience in the Old Testament (cf. 1 Samuel 16:7).

questions.question: Which theme in John 2 is developed through the miracle at Cana and the cleansing of the temple?
options: Jesus' authority and divine glory
The end of the world
The role of the Pharisees
The establishment of the synagogue
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus' authority and divine glory
questions.explanation: John 2:1-11 and 14-17 reveal Jesus’ divine authority and glory through signs and righteous zeal, foundational themes in John's Gospel.

questions.question: How does Jesus' interaction with his mother in John 2:3-5 illustrate the theme of obedience in Johannine literature?
options: His mother instructs the servants to obey Jesus' commands, showing trust in his divine mission
Jesus disobeys his mother
The disciples ignore Jesus' instructions
The servants refuse to listen
questions.correctAnswer: His mother instructs the servants to obey Jesus' commands, showing trust in his divine mission
questions.explanation: John 2:5 shows Mary telling the servants to do whatever Jesus commands, emphasizing obedience to Jesus as central to faith in John.

questions.question: True or False: According to John 2:23-24, many people believed in Jesus because of the miracles He performed at the Passover in Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: John 2:23 states many believed in Jesus when they saw the miracles at the Passover, but John 2:24 notes Jesus did not fully entrust Himself to them.

questions.question: What is the historical context of the 'changemakers' and animal sellers in the temple as described in John 2:14?
options: They facilitated temple sacrifices for pilgrims but were often accused of exploiting worshippers
They were Roman tax collectors
They were Pharisee rabbis
They were prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They facilitated temple sacrifices for pilgrims but were often accused of exploiting worshippers
questions.explanation: John 2:14 describes money changers and sellers of oxen, sheep, and doves who provided necessary services for temple worship but were criticized for commercializing sacred space.

questions.question: How does the miracle of turning water into wine in John 2 relate to the theme of 'new creation' in the Gospel of John?
options: It symbolizes transformation and abundance in the new creation inaugurated by Jesus
It indicates a return to the Mosaic law
It represents destruction of the old covenant
It shows Jesus' role as a prophet only
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes transformation and abundance in the new creation inaugurated by Jesus
questions.explanation: Water becoming wine (John 2:7-9) metaphorically reflects new creation themes, where Jesus brings transformation and fulfillment beyond old orders.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In John 2:11, the miracle at Cana is described as the 'beginning of ______' that revealed Jesus' glory.
options: signs
teachings
parables
sermons
questions.correctAnswer: signs
questions.explanation: John 2:11 calls the water-to-wine miracle the 'beginning of signs' through which Jesus manifested his glory.

questions.question: What literary device is employed in John 2:19-21 when Jesus speaks of destroying the temple and raising it in three days?
options: Metaphor
Simile
Hyperbole
Irony
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: Jesus uses metaphor in John 2:19-21 to refer to his body as the temple, predicting his death and resurrection.

theological.title: John Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from John Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the significance of Jesus turning water into wine at the marriage in Cana, as described in John 2?
options: It was Jesus' first public miracle, revealing His glory and divine authority.
It was a symbolic act of cleansing and purification for the guests.
It was a sign of Jesus' displeasure with the wedding hosts.
It was performed to demonstrate the superiority of Jewish customs.
questions.correctAnswer: It was Jesus' first public miracle, revealing His glory and divine authority.
questions.explanation: John 2:11 states this was the beginning of Jesus' miracles and manifested His glory. This act reveals Jesus' divine power, consistent with Old Testament signs of God's intervention (Exodus 7:19-21) and New Testament affirmations of Christ's divine nature (Hebrews 1:3; Colossians 1:15-17).

questions.question: In John 2, what does Jesus mean when He says to His mother, 'Mine hour is not yet come'?
options: His time to fully reveal His messianic mission and suffer had not yet arrived.
He was unwilling to help at the wedding celebration.
He did not want to perform miracles in public.
He was indicating that He did not know how to solve the problem.
questions.correctAnswer: His time to fully reveal His messianic mission and suffer had not yet arrived.
questions.explanation: John 2:4 reflects Jesus' awareness of the divinely appointed timing for His public mission and passion, which will culminate at the cross (John 7:30; 12:23-27). This aligns with prophetic timing seen in Isaiah 53 and Daniel 9:24-27.

questions.question: What instruction did Jesus give to the servants at the wedding in Cana?
options: Fill the waterpots with water and then draw some out to present to the ruler of the feast.
Bring more wine from the cellar immediately.
Mix the water with oil and serve it.
Offer the guests bread and fish instead of wine.
questions.correctAnswer: Fill the waterpots with water and then draw some out to present to the ruler of the feast.
questions.explanation: John 2:7-8 shows Jesus instructing the servants to fill jars with water and then to take some to the ruler of the feast, who discovers it has been miraculously changed into wine. This demonstrates Jesus' sovereign power over creation, reminiscent of creation's water-to-blood plague (Exodus 7:14-24).

questions.question: How does the ruler of the feast describe the wine Jesus provided?
options: He remarks that the good wine was kept until last, contrary to usual practice.
He complains the wine is inferior to what was served earlier.
He says the wine is too strong for the guests.
He is indifferent and does not comment on the wine.
questions.correctAnswer: He remarks that the good wine was kept until last, contrary to usual practice.
questions.explanation: John 2:10 states the ruler of the feast acknowledges that typically the best wine is served first, yet Jesus preserved the best wine for last. This signals the new covenant blessings being superior to the old and echoes prophetic themes of restoration (Jeremiah 31:31-34).

questions.question: What does Jesus' cleansing of the temple reveal about His attitude toward worship and sin?
options: He zealously defends the purity of God's house against commercial exploitation.
He endorses the current practices of the temple merchants.
He is indifferent to the temple's condition.
He promotes a new marketplace within the temple.
questions.correctAnswer: He zealously defends the purity of God's house against commercial exploitation.
questions.explanation: John 2:14-16 shows Jesus driving out sellers and money changers, emphasizing that the temple is His Father's house and not a place for commerce. This zeal fulfills Psalm 69:9 and illustrates God's demand for holiness (Leviticus 19:30; Malachi 3:1-3).

questions.question: What Old Testament prophecy do Jesus' disciples recall upon His cleansing of the temple?
options: The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up.
The Lord is my shepherd; I shall not want.
He was pierced for our transgressions.
The stone the builders rejected has become the cornerstone.
questions.correctAnswer: The zeal of thine house hath eaten me up.
questions.explanation: John 2:17 references Psalm 69:9, where the psalmist expresses zeal for God's house. This connects Jesus' actions to prophetic fulfillment and divine righteousness, demonstrating His messianic identity (Romans 15:3; Hebrews 10:5-7).

questions.question: What sign does Jesus give in response to the Jews' demand for a miraculous proof of His authority in the temple?
options: He says, 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.'
He performs another water-to-wine miracle.
He quotes the Ten Commandments.
He heals a blind man immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: He says, 'Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up.'
questions.explanation: John 2:19 records Jesus' enigmatic statement about His body as the temple. This foreshadows His death and resurrection, highlighting His role as the new temple and mediator of salvation (1 Corinthians 6:19; Ephesians 2:19-22; Isaiah 53:10).

questions.question: How do the Jews respond to Jesus' statement about destroying the temple and raising it in three days?
options: They say the temple took forty-six years to build and question how He could rebuild it so quickly.
They believe Him immediately and worship Him.
They ignore His words and continue their commerce.
They accuse Him of blasphemy openly.
questions.correctAnswer: They say the temple took forty-six years to build and question how He could rebuild it so quickly.
questions.explanation: John 2:20 shows the Jews' literal misunderstanding of Jesus' reference to His body as the temple, reflecting their limited comprehension of His messianic mission (Isaiah 53; Psalm 118:22; Luke 24:25-27).

questions.question: What does the 'temple of His body' refer to in Jesus' explanation?
options: His own physical body, which would be resurrected after three days.
The physical temple in Jerusalem.
The synagogue where He taught.
The community of believers.
questions.correctAnswer: His own physical body, which would be resurrected after three days.
questions.explanation: John 2:21 clarifies that Jesus was speaking metaphorically about His body as the temple, indicating His impending death and resurrection. This aligns with New Testament Christology emphasizing Jesus' resurrection as foundational (Romans 6:4; 1 Peter 1:3; Acts 2:24).

questions.question: After Jesus' resurrection, what do His disciples remember and come to believe according to John 2?
options: They remember His words about the temple and believe the Scripture and His statement.
They forget His teachings and are confused.
They reject His claim and scatter.
They focus only on the miracles and ignore His words.
questions.correctAnswer: They remember His words about the temple and believe the Scripture and His statement.
questions.explanation: John 2:22 explains that the disciples recalled Jesus' statement about the temple after His resurrection and believed both Scripture and His words, underscoring the fulfillment of prophecy and the centrality of the resurrection for faith (Luke 24:44-47; Romans 1:4).

questions.question: What is the significance of many believing in Jesus' name during the Passover feast in Jerusalem?
options: They believed because they saw the miracles Jesus performed.
They believed because of political pressure.
They believed because of the temple merchants' testimonies.
They did not actually believe but followed tradition.
questions.correctAnswer: They believed because they saw the miracles Jesus performed.
questions.explanation: John 2:23 states many believed in Jesus' name during the Passover because of the miracles He did, highlighting the role of signs in authenticating Jesus' messianic identity (John 20:30-31; Exodus 12:1-30; Acts 2:22).

questions.question: Why did Jesus not commit Himself fully to those who believed in Him at the Passover feast?
options: Because He knew all men and understood human hearts thoroughly.
Because He doubted their sincerity.
Because He wanted more miraculous signs.
Because He was afraid of the authorities.
questions.correctAnswer: Because He knew all men and understood human hearts thoroughly.
questions.explanation: John 2:24-25 explains that Jesus did not fully entrust Himself to them since He knew human nature and hearts completely, indicating His divine omniscience and discernment (1 Samuel 16:7; Jeremiah 17:10; Hebrews 4:13).

questions.question: What does the presence of six stone waterpots signify in the context of Jewish purification rites?
options: They were used according to Jewish purification customs, holding two or three firkins each.
They were ordinary containers for drinking water.
They were used for sacrificial offerings.
They were filled with wine from the start.
questions.correctAnswer: They were used according to Jewish purification customs, holding two or three firkins each.
questions.explanation: John 2:6 describes the waterpots as stone jars used for Jewish purification, emphasizing Jesus' respect for Jewish law while instituting a new covenant, consistent with Leviticus 15 and ceremonial cleansing practices (Hebrews 9:10).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is highlighted by Jesus’ miracle at Cana regarding the nature of His ministry?
options: Jesus' ministry inaugurates the new covenant and reveals His divine glory.
Jesus' ministry is limited to performing physical healings only.
Jesus denies any divine authority at this stage.
Jesus' ministry is primarily political.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus' ministry inaugurates the new covenant and reveals His divine glory.
questions.explanation: John 2:11 reveals this miracle as the beginning of Jesus' signs, signaling the inauguration of the new covenant (Jeremiah 31:31-34) and His divine glory (Isaiah 40:5; John 1:14).

questions.question: How does John 2 depict Jesus’ knowledge of humanity?
options: Jesus knows what is in man and does not need human testimony.
Jesus is ignorant of human hearts and depends on others.
Jesus judges people only by their outward actions.
Jesus trusts human testimony over His own knowledge.
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus knows what is in man and does not need human testimony.
questions.explanation: John 2:25 emphasizes Jesus' divine omniscience, knowing human hearts intimately, consistent with Scriptures like Psalm 139:1-4 and Hebrews 4:13.
